item.content:encoded:
Bugaboo Cloud: Smart Baby Car Seat

2020

Project Type: Master's Program Individual Project

Client: Bugaboo

Disciplines: interactive systems, concept design, 3D rendering and animation

Providing "kangaroo care" at a distance through the synchornization of breathing patterns between parent and baby.

Overview

The Bugaboo Cloud is a breathing seat cover that synchronizes with the parent’s breathing via the seatbelt sensor band. The
Cloud helps parents provide comfort to their young baby from the distance of their car seat at the front. Babies find the parent’s movement of their chest as they breath to be one of the most important sensation to help them calm down during stressful situations. The Cloud manages to provide this sensation at a distance with its force sensor on the sensor band that tracks the parent’s chest movement and the mini air pump that inflates the silicon air pockets inside the fabric of the breathing seat cover.

Conceptualization and Rapid Prototyping

Created concept prototypes in the form of user scenario sketches and lo-fi prototypes to present to potential users (parents) and improve the design based on their feedback.

The post Bugaboo Cloud: Smart Baby Car Seat appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.

item.content:encoded:
SenseGlove Manao VR Glove

2020

Project Type: Master's Program Group Project

Client: SenseGlove

Personal Role: electronics and interactive systems, 3D rendering and animation, 3D printing technician

Re-imagining the SenseGlove as a mobile, soft glove for improved immersion into the VR Environment

Overview

The diagram below showcases the 3 development areas of the project. My main contribution in the project were in developing the finger tracking technology and interactive system used in the final prototype design.

Electronics and Interactive Systems

For the final prototype showcase, I used the integrated flex sensors with Arduino to control the virtual hand in the interactive environment I created using Python and Blender 3D. This allowed us to test the final glove prototype with potential users and obtain a real-time simulation of their hand movement on the computer screen as it would be captured in a more complex VR simulation environment.

Final Prototype Concept

The post Senglove Manao: VR Glove appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.

This project marked the start of my interest in design and rapid prototyping with 3D printing and Arduino leading me to pursue a Masters in design at TU…

The post Remobility Stroke Rehabilitation appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.
item.content:encoded:
Remobility Stroke Rehabilitation

2018

Project Type: Extra-curricular Design Team

Client: UBC Biomedical Engineering Student Team

Personal Role: Lead Design and Mechanical Engineer

Additional Roles: arduino prototyping, 3D modelling and rendering, 3D printing

The modern stroke therapy device to motivate patients to meet their goals and regain mobility.

Designed, prototyped, and personally presented a novel medical device at the RESNA student competition finals in Washington, D.C. representing my multi-disciplinary team of 5 engineering students. This project marked the start of my interest in design and rapid prototyping with 3D printing and Arduino leading me to pursue a Masters in design at TU Delft a couple years later.

Design Brief

Stroke survirors often must partake in physical therapy to regain full function of their hands. With current methods being outdated, Remobility redefines rehabilitation through light/vibration feedback and improved patient/doctor interaction. As recommended by doctors interviewed, 3 exercise components were developed to target the 3 essential therapeutic movements. Each component contains sensors to activate the light and vibration when the user interacts with it correctly.

The post Remobility Stroke Rehabilitation appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.

Overview TEX(alive) is a fully 3D printed approach to explore shape changing interfaces and alive-like expressions including its…

The post Tex(alive): Animated Textile Toolkit appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.
item.content:encoded:
TEX(alive): Animated Textile Toolkit

2021

Project Type: Master's Graduation, Research Publication

Client: Delft University of Technology - Materials Experience Lab

Supervisors: Prof. Dr. Elvin Karana, Dr. Jun Wu, Alice Buso

Disciplines: shape-changing interfaces, material driven design (MDD), 3D printing, digital interactive tool

Publication: Designing Interactive Systems Conference 2022

Links: Publication - Conference Presentation Video - Conference Teaser Video - TU Delft Article on Graduation Project

Combining material driven design (MDD) with computational tools to aid designers in exploring the material experience of livingness in shape-changing interfaces.

Overview

TEX(alive) is a fully 3D printed approach to explore shape changing interfaces and alive-like expressions including its hardware augmented by the computational tool. The toolkit uses accessible 3D printed pneumatic actuators commonly used in soft robotics due to their controllability and ease of fabrication compared to other shape changing materials. The 3D printed pneumatic actuators can be arranged along a 3D printed textile composite to create a variety of shape morphologies. The hardware allows the user to control the kinetic parameters of the movement of the textile to create different expressions. Additionally, the computational design tool allows the designer to predict the shape and movement of the textile by digitally varying the location of the actuator. The toolkit was validated with various designers ranging from different levels of expertise with smart materials showing its potential as a design tool for easily exploring shape changing interfaces and alive-like expressions.

Material Exploration

Explored the effect of various 3D printing parameters on the creation of pneumatic actuators and the actuated response of parametric patterns (Grasshopper) 3D printed on textile to prototype shape-changing interfaces.

Shape Change Simulations in Grasshopper

Using Grasshopper, I developed a virtual tool that allows the designer to explore a variety of shape-forms that can be created with Textalive prior to testing it in a physical space. This type of simulation tool can help designers in scaling up creations with shape-changing interfaces in future design explorations. 

Creative Sessions with Material Designers

We invited 7 material designers to explore, play, and create with the Textalive toolkit in structured creative sessions. These sessions showcased the creative possibilities and new interactions that are unlocked when technical constraints are overcome with the use of a toolkit.

Resulting Concepts from Creative Sessions

Participants were asked to imagine future expressions or applications of shape-interfaces they could create with the Textalive toolkit. Their concepts were recreated in a studio environment and showcased below.

The post Tex(alive): Animated Textile Toolkit appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.

Pond Ottoman 2019   Project Type: Master’s Program – Individual Project Disciplines: furniture concept design, 3D rendering, 3D printing A peaceful ottoman designed to create a calming feeling like ripples on a pond. Process Beginning with simple wooden curves and ending with an interaction inspired by nature. The rings in the center create a calming interaction as they move like the ripples on a pond. The combination of the empty structure with the ripple interaction gives the user a weightless feeling to relax and think. Final Design and Prototype To showcase the pond-inspired interaction, I created a 3D printed scale prototype…

The post Pond Ottoman appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.
item.content:encoded:
Pond Ottoman

2019

 

Project Type: Master's Program - Individual Project

Disciplines: furniture concept design, 3D rendering, 3D printing

A peaceful ottoman designed to create a calming feeling like ripples on a pond.

Process

Beginning with simple wooden curves and ending with an interaction inspired by nature. The rings in the center create a calming interaction as they move like the ripples on a pond. The combination of the empty structure with the ripple interaction gives the user a weightless feeling to relax and think.

Final Design and Prototype

To showcase the pond-inspired interaction, I created a 3D printed scale prototype with and small cushion, which showcased the gentle response of the rings when weight was applied.

The post Pond Ottoman appeared first on Jose Martinez Castro.
